message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
int[] indices = IntStream.range(0, scores.length).boxed().sorted((i, j) -> Double.compare(scores[j], scores[i])).mapToInt(ele -> ele).toArray();
HashSet<Integer> topPossibleClusters = new HashSet<Integer>();
for(int i = 0; i < numClusters; i++) {
    topPossibleClusters.add(indices[i]);
}
<<<explanation>>>: Instead of using a HashMap to store the indices and values, you can use an IntStream to generate a range of integers from 0 to the length of the scores array. Then, sort this stream by comparing the scores at each index. This will give you an array of indices sorted by their corresponding scores. You can then add the top numClusters indices to your HashSet. This approach avoids the overhead of autoboxing and using a HashMap.
